title: The Kids of Rutherford County, Episode 4: Dedicated Public Servants
description: The lawsuit against Rutherford County comes to an end, but the hard part is actually getting everybody paid.
content: The lawyers settle their case on behalf of the children who were wrongfully arrested or illegally jailed by Rutherford County. The county ends its illegal detention policy, and some of the kids who were wronged by the system are paid. But none of the adults behind the illegal policies face serious consequences. So what has changed in Rutherford County, and what hasn’t?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: ‘You’re Just Scum’: Haley and Ramaswamy Tussle Onstage
description: An exchange over TikTok turned into a heated confrontation that ended with Nikki Haley calling Vivek Ramaswamy “scum.”
content: It quickly got personal. Then it turned ugly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘A Toast to Raising Alcohol Taxes’
description: What can be done to reduce the destructive effects of excessive drinking? A Times Opinion video proposes a simple but effective idea.
content: “A Toast to Raising Alcohol Taxes” is a five-minute Opinion video addressing the quiet drug epidemic facing our nation — excessive drinking. “Imagine a way,” the Times filmmakers ask, “to drastically cut the number of deaths on America’s roads, to spare many from fatal disease, something that could reduce violence and even unwanted pregnancies.” The good news, they inform us, is that it actually exists: raise taxes on alcohol. The bad news is that politicians are petrified to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Blue Lagoon in Iceland Temporarily Closes After Thousands of Earthquakes
description: The tourist attraction, a geothermal spa that is popular with Americans, said it would “carefully monitor the seismic developments” as a precautionary measure.
content: Thousands of earthquakes recorded over the past few days have led to the pre-emptive closure of the Blue Lagoon, an iconic tourist destination in Iceland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Man Charged With Firing Gun in Subway Station to Stop a Mugging
description: John Rote fired two shots in an effort to stop a homeless man from robbing a woman at a Manhattan station, officials said.
content: A Queens man who fired two shots in a Manhattan subway station in an effort to stop a homeless man from robbing a woman was charged on Wednesday with weapons counts and other crimes, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A Pocket Full of Pumpkin Flavor
description: Pumpkin empanadas, popular in communities along the U.S.-Mexico border, have a special place on the Thanksgiving table.
content: Every year after Halloween, when Yvette Marquez-Sharpnack’s carved jack-o’-lanterns looked soggy, her grandmother in El Paso saw an opportunity to repurpose them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Cozy Hudson Valley Bookshop With an Emphasis on Female Authors
description: Plus: handcrafted steamer trunks, a new Chinese restaurant in Lower Manhattan and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: For over ten years, the Jaipur, India-based brothers and founders of Trunks Company, Priyank and Paritosh Mehta, have been on a mission to revive the steamer trunk and support local artists who make them. This week, they’ll be exhibiting 11 of the most ornate examples of the company’s work at the Salon Art + Design fair at the Park Avenue Armory, from a library trunk with quilted leather lining that’s embedded with speakers and lit with LED spotlights to a hand-painted red, white and navy blue Games Island Trunk that unfolds to become a tiny casino featuring amusements like Jenga, poker and chess. About a dozen craftspeople work two to three months on each of the trunks, which are meant to be statement pieces in a home rather than accompanying their owners on a trip, says Paritosh. “We’ve been commissioned to craft a trunk in the shape of the Taj Mahal Palace by the hotel, and to make a trunk for a collector to display his watch collection,” he says. “We’re building a whole lifestyle around heritage trunks.” Next year, though, the company plans to debut its most practical collection to date: hand-painted trunks with wheels that one can actually travel with. Price on request, on view at the Park Avenue Armory from Nov. 9 through 13, thesalonny.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Albert Brooks: Defending My Life’ Review: Revisiting Past Hilarity
description: This actor, comic, writer and director is seen in a cinematic retrospective that celebrates his talent, but not always in a critically discerning way.
content: “Albert Brooks: Defending My Life,” a documentary about the venerable comedian, filmmaker, actor and writer, directed by his lifelong friend Rob Reiner, has the easy, amiable air of a career retrospective — wistful and hagiographic, it’s the kind of thing that usually accompanies a lifetime achievement award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Jeffery C. Mays
title: In N.Y.P.D.’s Harsh Tactics Under Adams, Critics See a Broken Promise
description: As a candidate, Eric Adams promised a new kind of policing. But some fear that increased stops and aggressive tactics will erode trust.
content: Edwin Raymond doubted he would ever be promoted to sergeant after he sued the New York Police Department over arrest quotas that fell hardest on Black and Latino men. But he had a prominent ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Palestinian Authority Open to Gaza Role if U.S. Backs 2-State Solution
description: The organization, which oversees the West Bank, says it will consider helping run Gaza after the war — if Washington pushes for the creation of a Palestinian state alongside the Israeli one.
content: The Palestinian Authority has told the Biden administration that it is open to a governance role in post-Hamas Gaza if the United States commits to a full-fledged two-state solution to end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, according to a top official of its parent, the Palestine Liberation Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: At a Hollywood Screening, Footage of Hamas Killing Israelis
description: After a screening at the Museum of Tolerance aimed to show the brutality of the Oct. 7 attack on Israeli civilians, fights broke out among protesters outside.
content: Having produced movies like “Pulp Fiction” and “Reservoir Dogs,” Lawrence Bender has a high tolerance for make-believe violence on film. But he wasn’t sure he could sit through raw footage of the real thing: the killings of Israeli civilians by Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: What to Know About the Sexual Side Effects of Antidepressants
description: S.S.R.I.s, the most widely prescribed antidepressants, frequently cause sexual problems. Here’s what patients can do about it.
content: Antidepressants have long been among the most widely prescribed drugs in the U.S. Their popularity only grew at the start of the coronavirus pandemic, when many people struggled with depression and anxiety. Some surveys have found a striking rise among adolescents, particularly teenage girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Why Are Oil Prices Falling While War Rages in the Middle East?
description: Energy markets have shrugged off the fighting between Israel and Hamas so far, focusing instead on forecasts of subdued demand.
content: Intense fighting is underway in a region that holds much of the world’s petroleum resources. Yet, after a few days of anxiety following the bloody Oct. 7 raids by Hamas militants in Israel, energy markets have been slumping. Brent crude, the international oil benchmark, is selling for about $80 a barrel, cheaper than when the fighting started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Journey to Bethlehem’ Review: No Room at the Inn? Try the Multiplex
description: It’s no “Home Alone” or “Jesus Christ Superstar,” but it does have Antonio Banderas as a song-slinging Herod and Lecrae as a quavering Angel Gabriel.
content: Christmas announces its coming earlier every year. We haven’t even hit Thanksgiving and here is this peculiar Nativity movie for, um, someone’s whole family, directed and co-written by Adam Anders. Anders, making his feature debut here, is a former “Glee” writer and music producer, and his co-writer, Peter Barsocchini, is a veteran of “High School Musical.” While their treatment of the ancient world is informed, to say the least, by their prior work, the scenario also feels like Hallmark pulped through a Disney strainer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Annie Ernaux Can Read Anywhere, So Long as It’s Quiet
description: “The first condition is silence,” says the 2022 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, whose most recent book is “The Young Man.” “The when and where do not matter.”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Graham Bowley
title: Germany Remembers Kristallnacht at a Fraught Moment
description: As reports of antisemitism surge in Germany and elsewhere, commemorations of the Nazi pogrom have taken on special resonance this year.
content: In a moment heavy with symbolism, Germany on Thursday marked the 85th anniversary of Kristallnacht, the eruption of murderous Nazi violence against the country’s Jews on the night of Nov. 9, 1938.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Neal E. Boudette
title: Biden Bolsters Union Support in Illinois
description: The trip, including a meeting with the president of the United Automobile Workers, offered the president a chance to celebrate a landmark labor deal.
content: President Biden pulled a red United Automobile Workers T-shirt over his button-down on Thursday and celebrated a landmark labor deal that kept a Stellantis manufacturing plant in business, using an appearance in Illinois to shore up crucial union support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy Misses a #MeToo Moment in Meloni’s Breakup
description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni dumped her partner after leaks about come-ons to colleagues. But workplace harassment is still being taken for granted.
content: Since Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s first female prime minister, announced over social media last month that she was dumping her longtime boyfriend, Italians have hardly stopped talking about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Will Pause Combat for Hours Each Day, the U.S. Said
description: Also, Senator Joe Manchin says he will not seek re-election. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: Israel has agreed to put in place regular daily four-hour pauses in its relentless assault on Hamas in northern Gaza to allow civilians to flee, according to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Meet the Champions of Nuance and Empathy We Need
description: Israelis and Palestinians who’ve lost family members to the conflict find strength in grieving together — and offer hope.
content: My columns from Israel and the West Bank over the past few weeks have been depressing, reflecting my fear that we’re on a bloody, downward spiral that will make everything worse. So let me share what I saw as an ember of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: WeWork’s Bankruptcy Tests Claims of a Co-Working Revolution
description: The business of offering offices on flexible, short leases will survive the company’s troubles, but commercial real estate experts say it will probably remain a niche.
content: In its heyday a few years ago, WeWork said it would reinvent offices. But the company never created a sustainable business or changed how most people worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Picasso Sells for $139.4 Million, Despite a Sagging Art Market
description: The blue-chip collection of Emily Fisher Landau sold at Sotheby’s on Wednesday night for a total of $406.4 million.
content: A brilliant blue painting by Pablo Picasso of his young mistress was crowned the prized lot of the November auction season so far after it sold at Sotheby’s in New York for $139.4 million, with buyer’s fees, on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Judge Approves JPMorgan’s $290 Million Settlement With Epstein Victims
description: The nation’s largest bank was sued for ignoring red flags about Jeffrey Epstein’s sex-trafficking operation while he was a client.
content: A federal judge on Thursday approved a settlement of a class-action lawsuit in which JPMorgan Chase will pay $290 million to sexual abuse victims of Jeffrey Epstein who claimed that the bank ignored warnings about the disgraced financier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Megyn Kelly Will Moderate the Next G.O.P. Debate, on NewsNation
description: The event, on Dec. 6, is an opportunity for an upstart cable news network to expand its relatively small viewership.
content: Megyn Kelly, whose high-flying career as a Fox News anchor fell to earth after an ill-advised move to NBC — and then remade herself as a conservative podcaster and radio host — is set to return to the political spotlight next month as a moderator for the next Republican primary debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz, Elisabetta Povoledo and Ruth Graham
title: Vatican Says Transgender People Can Be Baptized and Become Godparents
description: A document approved by Pope Francis lays out nuanced guidance in keeping with his vision of a more inclusive church, but it does not amount to a policy change in the church, the Vatican says.
content: Pope Francis, who has made reaching out to L.G.B.T.Q. Catholics a hallmark of his papacy, has made clear that transgender people can be baptized, serve as godparents and be witnesses at church weddings, furthering his vision of a more inclusive church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vaughn Vreeland
title: This Simple Hack Yields the Best Mashed Potatoes
description: Browning a little butter goes a long way to making a Thanksgiving staple all the better.
content: Mashed potatoes, while buttery and delicious, can also be a little uninspired. To me, they’ve always felt like filler on my Thanksgiving plate — an afterthought, more vehicle for gravy than anything else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Manchin Says He Will Not Seek Re-election, Dealing Blow to Democrats
description: The decision by Senator Joe Manchin III will leave open a seat in a deeply red state, threatening Democrats’ hold on the Senate.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III, the conservative West Virginia Democrat known for bipartisan deal-making and also for frustrating some of his party’s most ambitious policy goals, announced on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, dealing a blow to Democrats’ chances of holding the Senate next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: It’s Not Kids With the Cellphone Problem, It’s Parents
description: Banning phones in school is hard. But it’s the right thing to do.
content: The hardest rule I ever set for my kids was refusing them cellphones until high school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Hearing the Music in Black American English
description: The music of African languages comes through in the play “Purlie Victorious.”
content: Broadway, as always, is giving us lessons on language and its connection to music. The stellar new production of “Purlie Victorious,” not seen on Broadway since 1961, is Exhibit A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Our Go-To, Won’t-Fail Roasted Brussels Sprouts Recipe
description: You cook them in a cast-iron skillet, meaning the sheet pan is free for the 534 other dishes on your menu.
content: Chances are that you, savvy New York Times Cooking cooker, don’t exactly need a roasted brussels sprouts recipe. Maybe you play fast and loose with it, switching up the seasonings, bringing in the broiler. But winging a dish can be risky when it comes to dinner gatherings with multiple dishes (and people) to juggle, to say nothing of unfamiliar ovens and equipment. So lean on Mark Bittman’s popular go-to recipe, which starts the sprouts cut-side down on the stovetop (for maximum browning) and finishes them in the oven. Bonus: You cook your sprouts in a cast-iron pan, freeing up that sheet pan for any of the other 534 dishes on your menu.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 9, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 9, 2023.
content: An article on Wednesday about the singer Desire Marea misidentified the year of the Battle of Isandlwana. It occurred in 1879, not 1897.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Linda R. Hirshman, Who Challenged Stay-at-Home Mothers, Dies at 79
description: A feminist provocateur, she went on to write about the gay rights movement and transformative figures like the first two female Supreme Court justices.
content: Linda R. Hirshman, a union lawyer turned law and philosophy professor turned feminist provocateur, author and cultural historian who managed, to her delight, to enrage liberals and conservatives alike with an attack on so-called choice feminism, died on Oct. 31 in Burlington, Vt. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson Plan: ‘A Beginner’s Guide to Looking at the Universe’
description: In this lesson, students explore how the James Webb Space Telescope is changing what we see in the distant universe.
content: The James Webb Space Telescope is a giant leap in the history of stargazing. Our view of the universe will never be the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Kyle Marshall’s History Lessons, in Fragments
description: His company’s debut program at the Joyce Theater has three New York premieres, including one about the Black roots of rock.
content: Kyle Marshall’s dance “Onyx” has a historical subject: the Black roots of rock ‘n’ roll. But don’t expect the work — one of the three New York premieres that make up his company’s debut program at the Joyce Theater this week — to be a straightforward parade of Black artists and their jukebox hits. Marshall’s approach is exploratory and questioning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said yesterday that Gaza should be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority once the war ends, the strongest signal yet of the Biden administration’s hopes for the future of the conflict. But what Israel will do in Gaza is largely unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Are We Looking at George H.W. Biden?
description: Two aged, dutiful Washington insiders. One tough re-election road.
content: When you played second fiddle to a revered, charismatic, transformative president who chose you as his running mate not because you dazzled him but because you dully rounded him out, not because he saw you as the party’s future but because you were a link to its past, can you ever shine as brightly as you deserve to?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Houthi Rebels Shot Down a U.S. Drone Off Yemen’s Coast, Pentagon Says
description: The downing of a Reaper drone, the mainstay of the American military’s aerial surveillance fleet, was the latest escalation of violence between the U.S. and Iran-backed groups in Yemen, Iraq and Syria.
content: A U.S. military surveillance drone was shot down off the coast of Yemen on Wednesday by Iran-backed Houthi rebels, the Pentagon said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger
title: Ramaswamy Seemed to Call Zelensky a Nazi. His Campaign Says That’s Not What He Meant.
description: A spokeswoman for Mr. Ramaswamy acknowledged that, without context, his remark could be easily misunderstood.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy drew shock and criticism online on Wednesday when he appeared to accuse the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, who is Jewish, of being a Nazi — but Mr. Ramaswamy’s campaign insisted that wasn’t what he meant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Consider a throwback detective show, a new basketball documentary or a holiday baking extravaganza.
content: ‘Moonlighting’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: New Contract May Not Solve Hollywood Actors’ Troubles
description: An end to the monthslong labor fight is in sight, but the industry’s changing economics could temper some of the actors’ gains.
content: After months of strikes that shut down most of Hollywood, the end appears in sight. The SAG-AFTRA union that represents some 160,000 members tentatively agreed to a new contract with media giants that, if approved, will reinvigorate the $134 billion American movie and television business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harron Walker
title: Why More People Are Shaving Their Eyebrows — And How to Do It Yourself
description: The dramatic beauty look, once most closely associated with punks, goths and drag queens, is entering the mainstream.
content: There is something distinctly queer about shaved eyebrows: their presence, or rather absence, challenges our expectations about what a face should be. And indeed, for much of the past century, they were a signal of deviance from the norm — either because a person couldn’t fit in or because they refused to. Take the drag queen Divine, who in the filmmaker John Waters’s 1972 trash epic, “Pink Flamingos,” struts down a Baltimore sidewalk wearing a slinky wrap dress, peep-toe heels and a pair of impossibly arched brows. She is undeniably glamorous, yet her brows — painted by the makeup artist and costume designer Van Smith, who first removed Divine’s natural ones along with part of her hairline — stamp her face with a permanent glare, as if underlining her character’s self-declared status as “the filthiest person alive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: I Have Never Been to This Israel Before
description: After traveling across Israel and the West Bank, I now understand why so much has changed.
content: People warned me before I came to Tel Aviv a few days ago that the Israel of Oct. 7 is an Israel that I’ve never been to before. They were right. It is a place in which Israelis have never lived before, a nation that Israeli generals have never had to protect before, an ally that America has never had to defend before — certainly not with the urgency and resolve that would lead a U.S. president to fly over and buck up the whole nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Prices Fall Again, Renewing Fears of Deflation
description: Consumer prices declined for the second time in four months, while prices charged by factories and other large producers have now been tumbling for over a year.
content: Prices are falling again in China after a two-month reprieve, with households and businesses wary of spending even as state-controlled banks pump money into the construction of more factories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: 8 Excellent Asian Noodle Soups (in Three Boroughs)
description: In Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens you’ll find superlative versions of prawn mee, mohinga and more.
content: Last week I wrote about soup, which I suggested is not as popular as it once was, possibly because it is not cut out for the age of share plates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: 3 Things We Learned From Ivanka Trump’s Trial Testimony
description: The former president’s daughter said she had little knowledge of the financial documents at the heart of the civil fraud case.
content: Ivanka Trump spent five hours on the witness stand on Wednesday, two days after her father testified in a fraud trial that threatens his business empire as he kicks off another run for the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Watch Night’ Review: For Spacious Skies, for Rancorous Waves of Hate
description: Conceived in part by Bill T. Jones, this multigenre work at the Perelman Performing Arts Center is interested in homegrown prejudice, but lacks dramatic focus.
content: Entering the Perelman Performing Arts Center’s auditorium, you quickly notice detritus that looks as if it has been blown in from a bewildering protest: A few small American flags here, color copies of a Greetings From Hollywood postcard there, wrinkled fliers everywhere. Some of them are imprinted with the text of the Second Amendment, others a rallying cry: “We fight fascists.” Among the most eye-catching is an ad for N.R.A. memberships, with its promise of “$5,000 Accidental Death and Dismemberment insurance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: America’s Most Expensive ZIP Codes
description: California areas dominated the top 100 this year (and last).
content: If California’s home prices had physical weight, they’d tip the state into the Pacific Ocean. Among the 100 most expensive ZIP codes in the United States in 2023, 61 were found in the Golden State, according to a study by RealtyHop. New York was next, with 18 ZIP codes in the top 100. To compile the rankings, researchers analyzed more than 3.6 million active home listings from Jan. 1 to Oct. 15, using the median list price in each ZIP to identify the most expensive ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Senate Panel Punts Effort to Force Testimony in Supreme Court Ethics Inquiry
description: The Judiciary Committee postponed votes to issue subpoenas for benefactors of Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel Alito after Republicans threatened a politically charged fight.
content: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday abruptly put off its push to subpoena two conservative allies of Justices Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Clarence Thomas as part of a Supreme Court ethics inquiry that has met stiff resistance from Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Israel Accuses Freelance Photographers of Advance Knowledge of Oct. 7 Attack
description: The New York Times said there was “no evidence” to support such claims about its freelancer.
content: The Israeli government on Thursday accused freelance photographers for several major news organizations, including The New York Times, of being “accomplices” in the killing and abductions of Israeli soldiers and civilians by Hamas fighters — an allegation The Times vigorously denied about its freelancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Who Won the Third Republican Debate?
description: Nikki Haley stood out, absorbing attacks and doling out many of her own. But political observers wondered how any of the candidates onstage cut into former President Donald J. Trump’s dominance.
content: The third Republican presidential debate this year, held on Wednesday in Miami, was packed with heated exchanges over abortion policy, immigration and China as the candidates tried to shine as the front-runner, former President Donald J. Trump, once again declined to join them onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Carl Hulse
title: House Republicans Clash Over Spending Days Ahead of Shutdown Deadline
description: Party divisions forced Republicans to abandon two of their own spending measures this week as they toiled to agree on a stopgap spending bill to avert a shutdown next Saturday.
content: At odds with one another on spending, House Republicans abruptly scrapped their legislative work on Thursday and left Washington with little progress toward funding the government and no plan to avert a shutdown next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Behind the Story: How a Writer Prepared for a 40,000-Mile Trip
description: The dozens of books that T writer Aatish Taseer read before his journey through Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq, and what he learned from each pilgrimage.
content: Eighteen months ago, when the New York-based T writer at large Aatish Taseer began planning his reporting trips for this month’s three-part feature story — an exploration of religious travel in Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq — he was already well acquainted with the idea of pilgrimage. His first book, the 2009 memoir “Stranger to History,” opens with what is arguably the world’s best-known faith-motivated journey, the hajj to Mecca, and ends with what he describes as a personal pilgrimage to meet his estranged father in Pakistan. In Delhi, India, where Taseer grew up, quick trips for the purpose of worship were commonplace. “People would do a pilgrimage on an ordinary Sunday,” he says, “instead of going to an amusement park.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: The Enduring, Transformational Power of Pilgrimage
description: The writer Aatish Taseer embarked on a journey through Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq. What he learned was less a life-altering revelation and more a lesson in curiosity itself.
content: Travel, the movement of people from one place to another, has always existed. But long before we thought to travel for pleasure, we traveled for purpose: for commerce, and for faith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Claudia Gryvatz Copquin
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are five-bedroom in Moorestown, N.J., and a four-bedroom in Garden City, N.Y.
content: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 5,518-square-foot English Tudor house built in 1929 and updated in 2020, with a formal living room, family and media rooms, an eat-in kitchen with center island, two staircases, three gas fireplaces, an in-ground pool, a walled English garden, a bluestone patio, a large landscaped yard and a two-car garage, on 1.61 acres that back up to a golf course. Claire McHugh, Weichert Realtors, 609-332-2222, Weichert.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Two Studies on Greenland Reveal Ominous Signs for Sea Level Rise
description: Some glaciers on the island are melting at double the rate of just a few decades ago.
content: Greenland’s mountain glaciers and floating ice shelves are melting faster than they were just a few decades ago and becoming destabilized, according to two separate studies published this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Jill Stein Announces Third-Party Bid for President
description: Ms. Stein will seek the Green Party nomination, a spokesman said. Her last two campaigns with the party were unsuccessful.
content: Jill Stein, who ran unsuccessfully for president on the Green Party ticket in 2012 and 2016, will run again in 2024, she announced on Thursday — adding yet another name to the field even as the two major parties appear almost certain to nominate the same two candidates who ran in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Matisse and Derain: The Audacious ‘Wild Beasts’ of Fauvism in a Radiant Show
description: The leaders of a short-lived but consequential art movement that flourished early in the 20th century take center stage at the Met Museum.
content: If you ever took an art history survey in college, you may recall the blur of Fauvism. In the parade of projected images, it was the shocking flash of pure color that sped past as the course made its way to the more demanding rigors and longer shelf lives of Picasso’s “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon” and Cubism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff
title: When a Dancer’s Moves Include a Wheelchair
description: How Chelsie Hill, the founder of the Rollettes dance team in Los Angeles, created a sisterhood for women and girls with disabilities.
content: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natan Odenheimer
title: Archaeologists Look for Traces of Missing in Ashes of Hamas Attack
description: A team of about 15 have recovered the remains of at least 60 people so far, most of them from an Israeli village that suffered devastating losses.
content: Moshe Ajami, a veteran Israeli archaeologist, has spent decades sifting through the country’s southern desert to excavate lost ruins that date back more than 2,000 years. But in the past couple of weeks, he has been focused on searching the ashes of homes burned down by Hamas terrorists during last month’s surprise attack, looking for the bones, blood and teeth of Israelis who remain missing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Elisa Gutierrez and Anna Foley
title: The Biden Campaign Wants Democrats to Calm Down
description: Yes, President Biden’s team has seen the polls that show him struggling in a 2024 rematch with Donald Trump. But it says it’s focused on other things — like how well Democrats are doing at the ballot box.
content: Over the course of a few days this week, we got two pretty remarkable data points for the 2024 election. On Tuesday, Democrats had a very good night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes, John Koblin and Nicole Sperling
title: Striking Actors and Hollywood Studios Agree to a Deal
description: The agreement all but ends one of the longest labor crises in the history of the entertainment industry. Union members still have to approve the deal.
content: One of the longest labor crises in Hollywood history is finally coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Liam Stack
title: In Congress and on Campuses, ‘From the River to the Sea’ Inflames Debate
description: The pro-Palestinian rallying cry has become a fixture of protests in the United States and was a focus of the congressional censure of Representative Rashida Tlaib. It has a fraught history.
content: When House Republicans and a solid bloc of Democrats banded together this week to censure Representative Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, for her statements about the Israel-Gaza war, they homed in on her embrace and defense of one pro-Palestinian slogan they called unacceptable: “from the river to the sea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: I.O.C. Says It Was Target of Elaborate ‘Fake News’ Campaign
description: Olympic officials said the effort included fabricated quotes about the Israel-Gaza war and a four-part, Netflix-style documentary.
content: The International Olympic Committee issued an unusual statement on Thursday saying it had been targeted by “fake news posts” that it said contained “defamatory content, a fake narrative and false information.” The elaborate campaign included manufactured quotations from I.O.C. representatives, fake news stories citing those fabricated comments and even a Netflix-style documentary series released online and narrated by a voice purporting to be the actor Tom Cruise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: 8 Nonalcoholic Wines for the Thanksgiving Table
description: These alcohol-free wines will help everyone give thanks this Thanksgiving.
content: With wine, there’s no point in fighting Thanksgiving dinner’s kaleidoscope of flavors. It’s best to find an easy way to flatter them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Trump on the Stand
description: Courtroom fireworks and some risky admissions.
content: For the first time in about a decade, Donald Trump took the witness stand this week and testified extensively under oath in court. The setting was his civil fraud trial in Manhattan, where a judge is deciding what penalties he should face for inflating the value of his properties to secure favorable loan terms from banks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Marvels’ Review: You’ve Seen This Movie 32 Times Before
description: Brie Larson stars alongside two Disney+ stars in this trope-ridden franchise installment, the 33rd movie in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
content: As with a lot of studio-created girl groups, the women fronting “The Marvels” are carefully styled, wear coordinated outfits during their big numbers, have a few flashily choreographed moves and, because they’ve clearly put in the rehearsal time, know how to harmonize (more or less). The group has been created for maximum bankability, familiarity and relatability, and to that instrumental end, it delivers exactly what you expect of it and not a single thing, idea or beat more. Its members are nice, even at their most ostensibly fierce, and so unrelievedly bland that it feels like an affront, especially to all the women here doing so much hard work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Killer’ Review: He’s a Deadly Bore
description: Michael Fassbender stars as a loquaciously dull hit man in David Fincher’s latest film about bloody exploits.
content: David Fincher can’t get enough of that murderous stuff — his filmography bleedeth over with miscreants (“Alien 3”), home invaders (“Panic Room”) and multiple maniacs (“Seven,” “Zodiac,” “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” “Gone Girl”). During one of his periodic breaks from painting the big screen red, Fincher served as a producer and director on the Netflix show “Mindhunter,” another of his visually impeccable, morgue-cold creep-outs. This one was about F.B.I. agents profiling serial killers like Edmund Kemper, a ghoul whose silkily insinuating manner resonated more deeply than the show, which ended after two seasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Can A.I. and Lasers Cure Our Smartphone Addiction?
description: A first impression of Humane’s new magnetic Ai Pin: equal parts magical and awkward.
content: An aqua blue light appeared on my outstretched palm, showing a menu. Slowly, I circled my wrist to scroll, pressing an index finger and thumb together in a pinching motion to select an item. I wanted to send a text message. The device on my sweater, a two-inch square magnetic pin from a start-up called Humane, let out a soft “clink.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘The Curse’ Review: People Who Live in Glass Houses
description: Nathan Fielder and Benny Safdie’s breathtaking, uncomfortable series takes home-renovation TV into the heart of darkness.
content: “It’s a mishegas,” Whitney Siegel (Emma Stone), a convert to Judaism, says to her husband, Asher Siegel (Nathan Fielder), as they do a good deed for a needy family. “Mitzvah,” Asher corrects her. “Mishegas means something else.” (It means, roughly, “craziness” in Yiddish.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Jim Huylebroek
title: An Old Master’s Song for the Nation That Broke His Heart
description: For his fellow exiles, Sadiq Fitrat Nashenas, an 88-year-old star from a golden era, evokes the Afghanistan they left behind, and one that could have been.
content: For four nights before the concert, the old master had trouble sleeping. In his dreams, he was haunted by defeat after defeat — a failed exam, a knockout in the boxing ring. During the day, an upset stomach reduced his diet to gentle soup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Friday Briefing: Israel Expands Pauses in Combat
description: Plus, Hollywood is coming back to life.
content: Israel has agreed to put in place regular daily four-hour pauses in its relentless assault on Hamas in selected areas of northern Gaza to allow civilians to flee, a White House spokesman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin, Johnny Diaz and Amanda Holpuch
title: Jezebel, the Pioneering Feminist Website, Will Shut Down
description: Citing “economic headwinds rattling our business,” Jim Spanfeller, the chief executive of Jezebel’s parent company, G/O Media, announced the suspension of the publication and staff layoffs.
content: The parent company of the website Jezebel announced on Thursday that it was shutting down the site and laying off its staff, citing economic headwinds and shifting audience priorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Stephanie Saul
title: After Antisemitic Attacks, Colleges Debate What Kind of Speech Is Out of Bounds
description: Pro-Palestinian students say that they are speaking up for an oppressed people, but critics say that their rhetoric is deeply offensive.
content: In the days after the Hamas attack on Israel, Max Strozenberg, a first-year student at Northwestern University, experienced a couple of jarring incidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: In a U.S. First, a Commercial Plant Starts Pulling Carbon From the Air
description: The technique is expensive but it could help fight climate change. Backers hope fast growth can bring down costs.
content: In an open-air warehouse in California’s Central Valley, 40-foot-tall racks hold hundreds of trays filled with a white powder that turns crusty as it absorbs carbon dioxide from the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Do You Use Swear Words?
description: A guest essayist writes about the reasons people swear and the power behind cursing. Is profanity part of your vocabulary?
content: Do you use curse words? If you use them, do you ever think about why? Does it feel good to unleash some foul language? Does it get attention? Does it help you bond with others or fit into a group?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Your Favorite Song Is Now a Norteña
description: The EZ Band’s blend of norteña music and Top 40 hits offers some Americans a way to connect with their parents’ culture and exposes others to a new sound.
content: At first, Jaime Guevara’s version of “Hey There Delilah” sounds like just another cover of the Plain White T’s original. But some seconds in, an accordion enters the mix. Then, Guevara shifts his crooning from English to Spanish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Adam Goldman
title: Israeli Forces Have Limited Time in Gaza, U.S. Officials Say
description: Israel’s response to the Hamas attacks has fueled sympathy around the world for the Palestinian cause even as Israel continues to bury its dead.
content: The Israeli military has limited time to carry out its operations in Gaza before anger among Arabs in the region and frustration in the United States and other countries over the spiraling civilian death toll constrain Israel’s goal of eradicating Hamas, U.S. officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Investigator Stole Items From Dead Men, Prosecutors Say
description: An investigator with the Los Angeles County medical examiner’s office took a gold necklace and rare antique coins from two men whose deaths he was handling, the authorities said.
content: An investigator with the Los Angeles County medical examiner’s office has been charged with stealing items, including a gold necklace, from two dead men, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib, Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: In Mexico, Surveillance Orders That Read Like a Political Power List
description: The Mexico City attorney general’s office ordered the phone records of politicians and officials, court filings show. Many of the people targeted say they were singled out for political reasons.
content: A leading presidential candidate. The head of the country’s customs agency. At least three borough mayors in the capital. It’s a list that includes powerful members of Mexico’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: A Bundle of 18th-Century Love Letters Is Unsealed at Last
description: More than 100 letters, addressed to French sailors, were never delivered. They remained unopened for nearly 250 years, until a historian found them in Britain’s archives.
content: The ink has barely faded, and the paper has only slightly yellowed. For nearly 250 years, the letters, more than 100 of them, sat sealed in Britain’s National Archives, unopened and unexamined until a history professor stumbled upon them. He found, to his delight, a treasure trove bearing intimate details about romance and daily life in mid-18th-century France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Joe Biden Re-election Dilemma
description: The risk of a loss for the president is real, and no amount of political ego can disguise that.
content: Joe Biden should be far and away the favorite to win re-election in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Nic Antaya
title: ‘Our Family Can Have a Future’: Ford Workers on a New Union Contract
description: A couple who work at a Ford factory that was on strike for 41 days said the terms of a tentative contract agreement would be transformative for them.
content: Before autoworkers went on strike in September, Dave and Bailey Hodge were struggling to juggle the demands of working at a Ford Motor plant in Michigan and raising their young family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Home Secretary Stirs Political Storm After Writing Article Attacking the Police
description: The future of Suella Braverman hung in the balance after she wrote an incendiary opinion article. Downing Street said the piece was unauthorized.
content: One of Britain’s most senior cabinet ministers, Suella Braverman, has triggered political turmoil by writing a newspaper article that attacked the country’s largest police force over its approach to a pro-Palestinian protest, and implicitly challenged the authority of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Is Reading the Hottest Thing You Can Do as a Single Person?
description: Pop culture has conditioned us to believe that a meet-cute that doesn’t happen in a bookstore is hardly worth having. But is being an avid reader truly essential to romance?
content: One of the first questions men ask Angela Liu on dating apps is “What are you reading?” The question is a softball for Ms. Liu, a self-proclaimed lover of literature. “I really care about the human condition and emotions and stuff,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Garment Workers Reject Wage Hike in Bangladesh
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, November 9, 2023.
content: “Garment workers should remember that if they damage factories, they may have to return to their villages and live without employment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Finalizes Significant Overhaul in Federal Regulations
description: New rules from the Office of Management and Budget will change how the federal government weighs costs, enabling new efforts on climate change and poverty.
content: The Biden administration has overhauled how the federal government assesses the costs and benefits of regulation and some government spending programs, clearing a path for more aggressive efforts to fight climate change and help the poor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Dawoud Bey, Full Frame: On Richmond’s Trail of the Enslaved
description: In haunting studies of places charged with Black American history, a photographer celebrated for portraits now lets the land do the talking.
content: The urban parkland along the James River running through Richmond, Va., is true forest. Here grow maple, oak, hickory, cottonwood, sycamore, river birch, hackberry, fronds bowed under climbing English ivy, with winter creeper spreading underfoot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A First-Class Dinner Menu From the Titanic Could Fetch Thousands at Auction
description: The menu, dated April 11, 1912, is part of a larger sale of maritime items taking place this weekend in England.
content: There were oysters, salmon with Hollandaise sauce, beef, squab, duck, roast chicken, green peas, parsnip purée and Victoria pudding. The feast described is not a Thanksgiving meal, but a snapshot of what first-class passengers on the Titanic ate for dinner on April 11, 1912, when the ship left Queenstown, Ireland, for New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: The Sensory Transcendence of a French Meal, via the Big Screen
description: “The Taste of Things” is the latest movie to luxuriate in France’s gourmand tradition, a safe way of attracting audiences outside the country.
content: In France, a robust appetite is a virtue if not a heroic trait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Five Years After Devastating Fire, the Town of Paradise Rebuilds
description: The town is pushing forward with climate-proofing as residents return.
content: Five years ago, what would become the deadliest wildfire in California history erupted in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Alan Hevesi, New York Official Who Fell From Grace, Dies at 83
description: A state legislator from Queens and a city and state comptroller, he was forced to resign in a scandal and later imprisoned in a pay-to-play scheme.
content: Alan G. Hevesi, a cerebral, suave and blunt New York politician who spent 35 years as an elected official until he suffered a dizzying fall that led to his resignation as state comptroller and 20 months in prison for corruption, died on Thursday in the hamlet of East Meadow on Long Island. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Azaria
title: Hank Azaria: To Matthew Perry, God Was a Bunch of Drunks in a Room
description: Matthew Perry wanted to be remembered for helping people get sober. I was one of them.
content: Matthew Perry said that he wanted to be remembered as someone who helped people get sober, even more than he wanted to be remembered as a very funny, famous Friend. I think he’ll be remembered as both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Tim Scott’s Debate Night Date Night
description: A long-running mystery of Mr. Scott’s campaign was solved at the G.O.P. debate, and it had nothing to do with politics.
content: Senator Tim Scott’s most viral debate moment didn’t actually happen during the debate. It came shortly afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peder Schaefer and Campbell Robertson
title: Former Baltimore Prosecutor Found Guilty of Perjury in Federal Court
description: A jury found Marilyn Mosby, once the state’s attorney for Baltimore City, guilty of lying about hardships tied to the pandemic to withdraw retirement funds.
content: Marilyn Mosby, a former Baltimore prosecutor who rose to national prominence for pursuing charges against police officers in connection with the death of Freddie Gray, was found guilty in federal court on two counts of perjury for falsely claiming financial hardship to withdraw money from a retirement fund.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Youth (Spring)’ Review: Garment Rending
description: The documentarian Wang Bing examines the cloistered world of young textile workers in China.
content: Despite running three and a half hours, the documentary “Youth (Spring)” withholds a great deal. That isn’t necessarily a criticism. The film is the latest documentary from Wang Bing, a persistent and widely admired chronicler of China’s downtrodden — its migrants, its outsiders, its mental patients and its survivors of forced-labor camps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Deal Granting Amnesty to Separatists Sets Off Turmoil in Spain
description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez’s agreement with Catalan separatists will likely keep him in power, but it has provoked an upheaval.
content: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain sealed a deal to extend amnesty to Catalan separatists on Thursday in exchange for their political support, likely allowing him to stay in power but causing turmoil throughout Spain, doubts in Europe and questions about the country’s stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Pans the Republican Debate
description: Kimmel called the five candidates in the latest G.O.P. face-off “a Who’s Who of who has no chance to beat Donald Trump.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Saffitz
title: These Five Thanksgiving Pies Are a Dessert Lover’s Dream
description: Make one or all of these updated classics and brand-new favorites from Claire Saffitz.
content: Thanksgiving is a major production if you’re the host, and generally I encourage cutting a few corners. If it eases your workload, I say go ahead and buy the gravy or use the canned cranberry sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Frank Borman, Astronaut Who Led First Orbit of the Moon, Dies at 95
description: He commanded the 1968 Apollo 8 mission that carried three astronauts farther from Earth than anyone had ever traveled. He later led Eastern Airlines.
content: Frank Borman, the commander of NASA’s 1968 Apollo 8 spaceflight, whose astronauts became the first men to orbit the moon, captured the famed image known as Earthrise and read lines from Genesis to deliver a brief Christmastime uplift to a troubled America, died on Tuesday in Billings, Mont. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin
title: Sore After Working Out? Here’s How to Manage.
description: Post-exercise stiffness is a part of any fitness regimen, but many treatments don’t address the underlying cause. Here’s what actually works.
content: Maybe it was an intense spin class that put you over the edge, or reaching for a personal best in the squat. Perhaps it was dancing all night at a wedding reception, using muscles you haven’t worked in years. Whatever the cause, the next day you’re stiff, sore and moving a little slowly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: ad nauseam
description: This term has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The term ad nauseam has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 27 in “Their Reputations Precede Them. And That’s the Problem” by Andrew Keh:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Ukraine. Israel. Can America Support Two Wars and Still Handle China?
description: To U.S. allies in Asia, the sudden focus on Gaza risks progress on America’s long-delayed pivot to the Indo-Pacific region.
content: America’s long-promised pivot to Asia was finally gathering momentum — new security deals with the Philippines and India, expanded military exercises, and plans with allies to stay ahead of Chinese technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘This Much We Know’ Review: Asking Why After a Friend’s Death
description: L. Frances Henderson’s intricate debut documentary investigates a suicide, raising plenty of questions, including one about its own ethics.
content: Our yearning for answers and the limits of knowing are at the heart of the intricately crafted, unsettling documentary “This Much We Know.” The director L. Frances Henderson based this very personal debut on John D’Agata’s lauded book “About a Mountain,” which deftly yoked the suicide of a teenager in Las Vegas to the Department of Energy’s since-scuttled plans to use Yucca Mountain, 100 miles northwest of that city, as a repository for nuclear waste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: The Quiet Rage of Caregivers
description: Looking after a sick family member can mean putting your own life on hold, often with little recognition or outside support.
content: Ann Brenoff didn’t worry when her dogs returned from a walk without her husband in 2015. He often dropped their leashes and let them race up the steep driveway to their home in the canyons of Los Angeles. “But after 20 or 30 minutes, we said ‘OK, where’s Dad?’” said Ms. Brenoff, 73, whose two children were then teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Getting Hollywood Back Up and Running Won’t Be Easy
description: With the industry hustling to make up for months of lost work, juggling production schedules and the availability of actors and crew members will be complicated.
content: Daisy Edgar-Jones, the 25-year-old British actress with an increasingly crowded dance card, will soon experience just how complicated Hollywood’s rush to return to work is going to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Las Vegas Unions and MGM Resorts Reach Tentative Labor Agreement
description: The deal, the second in two days with a major resort operator, was announced on the day before a strike deadline set by two major unions.
content: Two unions representing hospitality workers announced on Thursday a tentative labor agreement with a second major Las Vegas hotel operator, MGM Resorts International, a day before a strike deadline set by the unions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Map of New York, With Details Up for Debate
description: A project from The Upshot captures residents’ disagreements over neighborhood names and borders.
content: In New York, the answer to the seemingly simple question “Where do you live?” can be contentious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith, Tripp Mickle and Photographs and Videos by Kelsey McClellan
title: Silicon Valley’s Big, Bold Sci-Fi Bet on the Device That Comes After the Smartphone
description: Humane, a company started by two former Apple employees, says its new artificial intelligence pin can stop all the scrolling. Can it live up to the hype?
content: Inside a former horse stable in the San Francisco neighborhood of SoMa, a wave of gentle chirps emerged from small, blinking devices pinned to the chests of employees at a start-up called Humane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: After Antidepressants, a Loss of Sexuality
description: Some patients are speaking up about lasting sexual problems after stopping antidepressants, a poorly understood condition.
content: Doctors and patients have long known that antidepressants can cause sexual problems. No libido. Pleasureless orgasms. Numb genitals. Well over half of people taking the drugs report such side effects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Manuela Andreoni
title: Coming Soon: More Oil, Gas and Coal
description: An alarming picture of planned fossil fuel production before the global climate talks.
content: It’s no secret that fossil fuels are still going strong, as we discussed last month. But a new United Nations-backed report paints an alarming picture of how dramatically coal, oil and gas production is expected to grow in the coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: With the Strikes Over, the Mood in Hollywood Is Decidedly Mixed
description: Celebratory feelings are competing with resentment over the work stoppage and worries about the business era that is coming.
content: It should be a rapturous time in Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Candidates Accuse Student Protesters of ‘Siding With Hamas’
description: Asked how they would address antisemitism, Republicans promised punishments for college activists. Only Vivek Ramaswamy dissented, describing pro-Palestinian protests as a free-speech issue.
content: The candidates on the Republican debate stage on Wednesday were largely united in declaring their full-throated support for the Israeli government in its war with Hamas. But on how to grapple with responses to the conflict within the United States, they differed — a little bit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: The Republican candidates rushed to line up behind Israel.
description: The five candidates at the third debate rejected calls for Israel to rein in its retaliation in Gaza after Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack.
content: The five Republican presidential candidates on Wednesday’s debate stage gave staunch support to Israel’s invasion of Gaza, rejecting pleas to rein in the conflict and calling on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to destroy Hamas, the Islamic militant group that killed 1,400 civilians and Israeli soldiers in a surprise attack last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Trump Family Trial Style
description: Ivanka Trump and her siblings dress for court — and the cameras.
content: The New York attorney general’s office has finished presenting its case in the civil fraud trial of former President Donald J. Trump. The first act of the first episode in the extended series known as the Trump lawsuits has come to an end. (The defense begins next week, and four more criminal cases are pending.) The show, however, is only beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: 3 Charged With Running Prostitution Service Used by Politicians and Others
description: The Justice Department did not name the clients of what it called the “high-end brothel network,” who were also said to include military officers, executives and government contractors.
content: The Justice Department announced charges on Wednesday against three people accused of running a “high-end brothel network” in the Washington and Boston suburbs and unveiled an investigation into potentially hundreds of high-profile clients who had paid for sexual services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov
title: Holocaust Survivors in Israel Faced Fresh Horror When Hamas Attacked
description: At least one Holocaust survivor was killed during the Oct. 7 attack. Others pressed against safe room doors to keep assailants out. One saw a video of her grandson’s abduction.
content: Moshe Ridler’s life ended much the way it began, at the hands of people who wanted to kill him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Popovich
title: America’s New Wildfire Risk Goes Beyond Forests
description: Grassland and shrubland fires burn more land and destroy more homes across the United States than forest fires, a new study found.
content: Forest fires may get more attention, but a new study reveals that grassland fires are more widespread and destructive across the United States. Almost every year since 1990, the study found, grass and shrub fires burned more land than forest fires did, and they destroyed more homes, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Kidnapped Father of Colombian Soccer Star Is Freed
description: Luis Manuel Díaz was abducted 12 days ago by a guerrilla group called the National Liberation Army.
content: The father of Luis Díaz, a Colombian soccer star for the English club Liverpool, was freed on Thursday after he was kidnapped by a guerrilla group, Colombian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul and Katie Van Syckle
title: Michelle Williams, Julianne Moore and Salman Rushdie Hit New York Galas
description: Actors reacted to a tentative deal to end their strike at a Creative Time fund-raiser, and the New York Public Library hosted its annual Library Lions gala.
content: On Wednesday night, inside a cavernous event space on the Lower East Side, at the annual gala for the public art organization Creative Time, the actor Jeremy Strong said the news that striking actors and Hollywood studios had reached a tentative deal, “went around the room like wildfire.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Gilbert
title: Dr. Ruth Saved People’s Sex Lives. Now She Wants to Cure Loneliness.
description: Taking the lessons of pandemic isolation — and her adolescent diary — Dr. Ruth Westheimer, 95, decided she should be New York’s Loneliness Ambassador. And so she is.
content: “I still will talk about orgasms,” Dr. Ruth Westheimer said during a conversation over the summer. “I still will talk about sexual dysfunction. But I have done that.” She had recently turned 95, and after a long and spirited career as America’s most famous and least likely sex counselor, she was driven by a new challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Music Executive L.A. Reid Is Accused of Sexual Assault in Lawsuit
description: The lawsuit, filed by Drew Dixon in federal court in Manhattan under the Adult Survivors Act, says that Mr. Reid’s misconduct cut short her career in music.
content: The Grammy-winning music executive Antonio Reid, who is known as L.A. and rose in the industry working with artists including Usher and TLC, has been accused of sexual assault and harassment in a lawsuit by Drew Dixon, who worked for Mr. Reid at Arista Records.

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Mysterious Case of Kitsy Rainey’ Review: Mikel Murfi’s Trilogy Has Bittersweet End
description: At Irish Arts Center, the actor delivers the final installment of his solo plays about the cobbler Pat and his eccentric beloved.
content: Falling in love came as a surprise to Pat Farnon — a late-life development he hadn’t been looking for any more than he’d been looking for the marriage proposal that set that romance in motion. When a whirlwind of a woman named Kitsy Rainey asked him to marry her even though they’d never so much as dated, he acquiesced.

description: David DePape, 43, faces charges of attempted kidnapping and assault on an immediate family member of a federal official in the 2022 attack against Paul Pelosi.

title: 35 Years After Its Debut, Tracy Chapman’s ‘Fast Car’ Wins a Song of the Year Award
description: She is the first Black songwriter to receive the honor from the Country Music Awards. Her 1988 hit reached a new generation of fans as a cover by Luke Combs.
content: Tracy Chapman won song of the year at the Country Music Awards on Wednesday for “Fast Car,” a folk ballad that topped the country charts more than three decades after it was first released thanks to a cover by the singer Luke Combs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Robert De Niro’s Company Is Found Liable for Gender Discrimination
description: Graham Chase Robinson, a former assistant of Mr. De Niro’s, was awarded $1.3 million by a jury. She said she was assigned “stereotypically female” job responsibilities.
content: A federal jury in Manhattan on Thursday found Robert De Niro’s company liable for gender discrimination against a former employee who claimed that the actor assigned her “stereotypically female” job responsibilities such as washing his sheets and attending to his home even as she climbed the ranks of his company, awarding her $1.3 million in damages.

Before she gets to her long list of tasks, she bakes a pie with ease, even joy, because she does “make a good pie.” She then follows the instructions for her duties literally — when asked to dust the furniture, she sprinkles powder all over it.

title: ‘Dream Scenario’ Review: Space Invader
description: Nicolas Cage plays a mild-mannered professor who inexplicably wanders into others’ dreams in this wonderfully weird dark comedy.
content: Balding, bespectacled and bowed by the weight of a thousand disappointments, Paul Matthews (Nicolas Cage) moves through “Dream Scenario” with a schlubby passivity. At the college where he teaches evolutionary biology, his students sigh and fidget; during a lesson on zebras, he explains that their stripes keep them safe by ensuring that they don’t stand out from the herd. Not standing out is Paul’s entire vibe.

content: “I always enjoy it when Calvin and Hobbes argue,” the cartoonist Bill Watterson once wrote of the wildly popular comic strip he drew in the ’80s and ’90s about a 6-year-old boy named Calvin and his best friend, a tiger named Hobbes. “A funny conversation is more interesting to me than a one-liner.”

title: F.B.I. to Move Headquarters to Maryland

content: The Biden administration has chosen a vacant lot in Greenbelt, Md., for the new headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, despite the lingering concerns of some senior bureau officials, four people familiar with the situation said late Wednesday.

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Nov. 15, 2023
description: How might declining fertility rates affect the world’s future well-being?
content: Economists and demographers who study population size project that the world’s population will reach a peak of about 10 billion people around 2085, if not earlier. Thereafter, the population is not expected to plateau, but instead decline to less than two billion about 300 years later, over perhaps 10 generations. Factors that influence population size of a country include fertility, mortality, migration and age structure. One of the results of population decline may include reduced economic growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Manodrome’ Review: The Manosphere Gets a Crude Awakening
description: An unemployed dad-to-be is seduced by a misogynist group who call themselves “the guys” in this sensationalizing drama starring Jesse Eisenberg.
content: The word “Manodrome,” the title of a new film starring Jesse Eisenberg, is a riff on the “manosphere” — a catchall term for misogynist online communities including so-called incels and men’s rights activists. If your first instinct, like mine, is to snicker, know that this self-important drama is devoid of humor.

content: A judge decided on Thursday that rap lyrics by the Atlanta artist Young Thug and his collaborators will be allowed as evidence in the racketeering trial of YSL, a chart-topping hip-hop label and collective that prosecutors say is also a criminal street gang responsible for violent crimes.

title: ‘Fear of Flying’ Is 50. What Happened to Its Dream of Freedom Through Sex?
description: With its feminist take on sexual pleasure, Erica Jong’s novel caused a sensation in 1973. But the revolution Jong promoted never came to pass.
content: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies. “Fear of Flying,” a book so sexually frank that you may have found it hidden in your mother’s underwear drawer, broke new ground in the explicitness of writing by and for women. Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire. She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.

description: He masterminded the building of a transoceanic fiber-optics network to speed the internet and phone traffic. But in five years the company went bankrupt in a historic failure.
content: Gary Winnick, a former junk-bond salesman who in 1997 founded Global Crossing, a telecommunications company that laid fiber-optic cable underwater around the world to speed internet and phone traffic, but that imploded five years later under billions of dollars in debt, died on Saturday at his estate in Los Angeles. He was 76.

content: Mati, the employee at the center of the hushed and absorbing documentary “A Still Small Voice,” reports for duty at an ordinary-looking office. There are cubicles, roller chairs, a water cooler and flat lighting that the director, Luke Lorentzen, would never dishonor by gussying up with a lamp. These are the chaplains’ quarters at The Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, and Mati and her colleagues are here to comfort the dying and the families of the dead — to transform this 1,134-bed institution into a sacred space. They are Olympian empaths and they are exhausted.

title: ‘Orlando, My Political Biography’ Review: A Collective Approach to Joy
description: The filmmaker Paul B. Preciado shares the title role with 20 trans and nonbinary performers to make a point about the cage of identity.
content: Few movies this year have lived in my head as long and as happily as “Orlando: My Political Biography,” which I’ve been thinking about since I first saw it in September. Written and directed by the Spanish-born philosopher and activist Paul B. Preciado — a trans man making his feature directing debut — the movie is, at its simplest, an essayistic documentary about transgender and nonbinary identity that draws inspiration from Virginia Woolf’s novel “Orlando: A Biography.” Yet trying to squeeze “My Political Biography” into a tidy categorical box is fundamentally at odds with Preciado’s expansive project, which is at once an argument, a confession, a celebration and a road map.
